title: Surfers invent floating trash bin to clean up world's oceans
desc: Two Australian surfers are trying to tackle the planet's water pollution problem head-on, by developing a device that functions as an automated floating trash bin for the world's oceans

title: Is the Doomsday Clock still relevant?
desc: Seven minutes to midnight. Five minutes to midnight. Three minutes to midnight

title: State of California flouts its own enviro laws, claims county threatening multi-million-dollar suit
desc: Sacramento County is threatening to fine Caltrans millions in taxpayer dollars for drilling hundreds of wells over a period of decades in violation of laws aimed at protecting groundwater, records show.

title: Plastic-laden plankton poop could be disastrous
desc: The amount of plastic in our oceans is now popping up as gigantic islands and set to outpace the global fish population by 2050.

title: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
desc: President Obama will announce Tuesday he is planning to sidestep Congress to implement a national plan to combat climate change that will include the first-ever federal regulations on carbon dioxide emitted by existing power plants, despite adamant opposition from Republicans and some energy producers.

title: China's smog drives some to buy Canadian air in a can
desc: It's come to this.

title: Australia approves dumping dredged mud around Great Barrier Reef
desc: Australia approved a plan to dump large amounts of mud and sediment into the oceans surrounding the Great Barrier Reef in order to make room for developers to expand a coal port on the country's eastern coast on Friday.

title: Suits claim Love Canal still oozing 35 years later
desc: Thirty-five years after Love Canal's oozing toxic waste scared away a neighborhood and became a symbol of environmental catastrophe, history could be repeating itself.

title: Welcome to Hell: Photographer documents Africa’s e-waste nightmare
desc: Slag heaps of rusting electronics, old refrigerators and monitors are scattered everywhere in Agbogbloshie, a dumping ground in Ghana for electronic waste from the rest of the world -- including the United States.

title: Officials begin testing mysterious goo linked to San Francisco Bay Area bird deaths
desc: San Francisco Bay Area officials have begun laboratory tests and necropsies on dead seabirds found coated with a mysterious substance that looks and feels like dirty rubber cement.

title: Two-headed baby salamander isn't radioactive, but it is weird
desc: Just call them "Arne" and "Sebastian." Those are the monikers given to the two separate heads of one baby salamander that was born last week in a lab in Israel.

title: UN touts Climate Summit successes
desc: U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon lauded the achievements of world leaders attending the Climate Summit in New York this week, touting, in particular, initiatives around carbon pricing and cutting emissions.

title: Study says raising beef creates more pollution than pork, poultry or dairy
desc: Raising beef for the American dinner table does far more damage to the environment than producing pork, poultry, eggs or dairy, a new study says.

title: UN finding on climate change is just a bunch of hot air, new report claims
desc: A U.N.-commissioned panel says global climate change is hurting the growth of crops, affecting the quality of water supplies and forcing wildlife to change the way they live – but what if it’s all just smoke and mirrors?

title: New ozone-destroying chemicals discovered in atmosphere, study says
desc: Four new man-made, ozone-destroying chemicals have been discovered in the upper atmosphere, and appear to be slowing the recovery of the ozone hole, according to a new report.

title: Solar-powered plane begins historic cross-country flight
desc: A solar-powered airplane that can fly day and night without using a single drop of fuel embarked on an unprecedented flight across the United States Friday.

title: UN calls for ‘all hands on deck’ to tackle climate change
desc: U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urged world leaders to throw their weight fully behind the effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions on Tuesday, describing climate change as “the defining issue” of our time.

title: Deadly coral diseases surge near dredging sites
desc: In a first study of its kind, researchers have linked dredging to increased sickness in nearby coral reefs.

title: Researchers surprised by levels of harmful ozone found in northern Colorado mountains
desc: Researchers say they're surprised by how much harmful ozone and ozone-causing chemicals are drifting into the Colorado mountains from urban and rural areas below.

title: Pollution from Asia strengthening storms in North America, study finds
desc: Pollution from China's coal-burning power plants is pumping up winter storms over the northwest Pacific Ocean and changing North America's weather, a new study finds.

title: Study claims 2010 BP oil spill left 'bathtub ring' on sea floor
desc: The BP oil spill left an oily "bathub ring" on the sea floor that's about the size of Rhode Island, new research shows.

title: Big methane burp: Cow farts a greater problem than EPA previously thought, study says
desc: The United States is spewing 50 percent more methane -- a potent heat-trapping gas -- than the federal government estimates, a new comprehensive scientific study says. Guess where it comes from?

title: Antarctic ozone hole hits 2013 peak size
desc: The Antarctic ozone hole reached its biggest extent for the year on Sept.

title: Molasses spill suffocating Hawaiian fish
desc: The spill that dumped hundreds of thousands of gallons of molasses into Honolulu Harbor last week is suffocating the harbor's underwater inhabitants

title: Beautiful, eerie fluorescent glow of Hong Kong seas indicates harmful algal bloom at work
desc: Eerie fluorescent blue patches of water glimmering off Hong Kong's seashore are magnificent, disturbing and potentially toxic, marine biologists say.

title: Scientists, researchers explore replanting trees to help catch pollution
desc: One of the nation's largest chemical companies and one of its oldest conservation groups have forged an unlikely partnership that seeks to recreate some of a long-gone forest to curb pollution.

title: There's a new species taking over at Chernobyl
desc: What happens when humans abandon 1,600 square miles because of radioactivity?

title: China, other Asian countries chief source of 8.8 million tons of plastics that hit ocean
desc: Each year about 8.8 million tons of plastic ends up in the world oceans, a quantity much higher than previous estimates, according to a new study that tracked marine debris from its source.

title: Last minute deal salvaged UN climate talks
desc: A last-minute deal that salvaged U.N. climate talks from collapse early Sunday sends a signal the rich-poor divide that long held up progress can be overcome with a year to go before a landmark pact is supposed to be adopted in Paris.

title: New scientific study estimates nearly 270,000 tons of plastic floating in world's oceans
desc: A new study estimates nearly 270,000 tons of plastic is floating in the world's oceans. That's enough to fill more than 38,500 garbage trucks.

title: Cavemen discovered recycling, Israeli researchers say
desc: If you thought recycling was just a modern phenomenon championed by environmentalists and concerned urbanites - think again.

title: Samsung's Solve for Tomorrow contest inspires students to pursue STEM
desc: Samantha Hoover, 14, said it didn’t sink in that she would be presenting work she did for a school project at the 2015 Samsung Solve for Tomorrow event in New York City until she stepped on the plane. It was the first visit to the city for the ninth grader from James Campbell High School in Ewa Beach, Hawaii.

title: Japan’s 'toxic' monster creeping towards US
desc: An enormous debris field is creeping toward the U.S. in the wake of the massive earthquake and tsunami that shook Japan in 2011, killing nearly 16,000 people and launching 1.5 million tons of floating objects into the sea.

title: Greenhouse gases hit a record high in 2011, UN agency says
desc: Earth averaged 390 parts per million of heat-trapping carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, up 40 percent from before the Industrial Age when levels were about 275 parts per million.

title: University of Michigan program aims to bolster scientific basis of Great Lakes cleanup effort
desc: The University of Michigan is establishing a research program designed to make sure the federal government bases decisions in its billion-dollar battle to clean up the Great Lakes on solid scien...

title: Here's the story behind the 'mutant Fukushima daisies'
desc: The Internet is aflutter over two rather bizarre photographs of what appear to be daisies taken near the Fukushima nuclear disaster site in Japan.
